Mendes, Victor Melo TrAnsLATion: AmeriConsulta ediToriAL revision: Charles Barrett desiGn: José Brandão | Susana Brito [Atelier B2] prinTed By: Textype THis prinTinG: 2,000 copies paralelo@flad.pt Legal deposit: 269 114/07 ISSN 1646-883X © Copyright: Luso-American Development Foundation All rights reserved Never before have the Portuguese shown such interest in an American presidential race dear reader “ Too close to call” is the phrase we’ve read and heard most during the coverage of the United States presidential race. The lively dispute between candidates for the Democratic ticket has sparked unparalleled interest, not only in the US (where political participation and voter interest have skyrocketed), but throughout the world. Caught up in the electoral fever, the Portuguese have shown an unprecedented interest in the American presidential race. This issue of Parallel turns the spotlight on the race for the White House: the involvement of Portuguese immigrants living in the United States and the impact the end result will have on America’s foreign policy. It all makes for enlightening reading you won’t want to miss. In this spring-summer issue we also discuss FLAD’s support for the MIT program, an initiative that promises to contribute to Portugal’s development in the fields of science, technology and education. In our development section, we take a revealing look at CoHITeC and its drive to spawn start-up businesses based on innovative projects. If culture and the humanities are your bag, don’t miss our report on “Wings over America,” the literary lecture series that, theatrically speaking, has played to packed houses. For several months enthusiastic audiences have come to FLAD’s auditorium to hear Portuguese writers give their close-up and personal views of some of the greatest names in American literature. Also in the limelight in this issue of Parallel are two breakthrough initiatives sponsored by the Luso-American Foundation. one is the all-new Antero de Quental exchange Agreement, which will be sending Azorean students and university professors to US universities. The other is a two-pronged initiative now getting its second wind. With FLAD sponsorship, Portuguese journalists from the Azores (under the Alfredo Mesquita Program) and the mainland (under the José Rodrigues Miguéis Program) will be heading to the US to hone their skills and broaden their knowledge base. And speaking of broad bases… we are sure there is something for everyone in this second issue of Parallel, which features everything from science to cinema. Puff up your pillow and pour yourself some port. You’re in for an enjoyable read! sArA pinA Parallel no. 2 | SPRING | SUMMER 2008 contents special USA‘08 ELECTIONS 06 | PRESS REVIEW 18 | Choosing the next US president 26 | Campaign funding and the internet 30 | Hillary and the boomer girls 44 [cuLTure] Portuguese writers discuss American writers 46 | Interview with Eduardo Lourenço 50 | Portuguese journalists in the US 54 | Antero de Quental Agreement: Portuguese and American student exchange program 10 [porTuGAL And THe us] Interview with Portuguese-American Senator Marc Pacheco in Boston 14 | Portuguese language throughout the world tabtoons@telus.net | Caglecartoons.com FRONT COVER special Feature: The us presidential race 16 pages SPECIAL FEATURE Spring | Summer 2008 02 Obama’s virtual campaign funds Hillary and the boomer girls McCain’s shoo-in Parallel no. 2 | SPRING | SUMMER 2008 3 ’08 US Presidential race ISSN 1646-883X Both sides of the Atlantic: Political participation Portuguese language throughout the world Portuguese authors discuss their favorite American writers Cowboys, myths and movies an exclusive interview with Eduardo Lourenço 21 | Portuguese Americans and politics by António Vicente 24 | The US presidential race and the European Union by José Cutileiro 28 | Latin-American influence by Michael Werz 62 | The third bank of the river by Mário Mesquita
